Author: Marie Curie

Author: Frederick Lewis Donaldson

Politics without principle.From a sermon given by Frederick Lewis Donaldson in Westminster Abbey, London, on March 20, 1925.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: One, remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. Two, never give up work. Work gives you meaning and purpose and life is empty without it. Three, if you are lucky enough to find love, remember it is there and don't throw it away.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: Somewhere, something incredible is waiting to be known.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: The important thing is to not stop questioning. Curiosity has its own reason for existence. One cannot help but be in awe when he contemplates the mysteries of eternity, of life, of the marvelous structure of reality. It is enough if one tries merely to comprehend a little of this mystery each day.—"Old Man's Advice to Youth: 'Never Lose a Holy Curiosity.'"LIFE Magazine (2 May 1955) p. 64

Author: Douglas Adams,  The Salmon of Doubt: Hitchhiking the Galaxy One Last Time
Quote: The fact that we live at the bottom of a deep gravity well, on the surface of a gas covered planet going around a nuclear fireball 90 million miles away and think this to be normal is obviously some indication of how skewed our perspective tends to be.

Author: Albert Einstein,  The World As I See It
Quote: The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion that stands at the cradle of true art and true science.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: We are just an advanced breed of monkeys on a minor planet of a very average star. But we can understand the Universe. That makes us something very special.

Author: Terry Pratchett,  Small Gods
Quote: Time is a drug. Too much of it kills you.

Author: Clive James
Quote: Common sense and a sense of humor are the same thing, moving at different speeds. A sense of humor is just common sense, dancing.

Author: Niels Bohr
Quote: An expert is a person who has made all the mistakes that can be made in a very narrow field.

Author: Dan Brown,  Angels & Demons
Quote: Science and religion are not at odds. Science is simply too young to understand.

Author: Arthur C. Clarke
Quote: I'm sure the universe is full of intelligent life. It's just been too intelligent to come here.

Author: Terry Pratchett,  Lords and Ladies
Quote: In the beginning there was nothing, which exploded.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: Everything must be made as simple as possible. But not simpler.

Author: Christopher Hitchens

Author: John Keats,  Ode on a Grecian Urn and Other Poems
Quote: Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard, are sweeter

Author: Charles Darwin,  The Life & Letters of Charles Darwin
Quote: A man who dares to waste one hour of time has not discovered the value of life.

Author: Douglas Adams,  The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
Quote: Space is big. You just won't believe how vastly, hugely, mind-bogglingly big it is. I mean, you may think it's a long way down the road to the chemist's, but that's just peanuts to space.

Author: Marie Curie
Quote: Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood. Now is the time to understand more, so that we may fear less.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: The good thing about science is that it's true whether or not you believe in it.

Author: Isaac Newton,  The Correspondence Of Isaac Newton
Quote: If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of Giants.

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
Quote: Science is not only compatible with spirituality; it is a profound source of spirituality.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: If the facts don't fit the theory, change the facts.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: It would be possible to describe everything scientifically, but it would make no sense; it would be without meaning, as if you described a Beethoven symphony as a variation of wave pressure.

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche
Quote: A thinker sees his own actions as experiments and questions--as attempts to find out something. Success and failure are for him answers above all.

Author: Carl Sagan,  Cosmos
Quote: If you wish to make an apple pie from scratch, you must first invent the universe.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: For me, I am driven by two main philosophies: know more today about the world than I knew yesterday and lessen the suffering of others. You'd be surprised how far that gets you.

Author: Arthur C. Clarke,  Profiles of the Future: An Inquiry Into the Limits of the Possible
Quote: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.

Author: Douglas Adams,  The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
Quote: So this is it,"said Arthur, "We are going to die.""Yes,"said Ford, "except... no! Wait a minute!"He suddenly lunged across the chamber at something behind Arthur's line of vision. "What's this switch?"he cried."What? Where?"cried Arthur, twisting round."No, I was only fooling,"said Ford, "we are going to die after all.

Author: David Mitchell,  Cloud Atlas
Quote: I believe there is another world waiting for us. A better world. And I'll be waiting for you there.

Author: Sarah Williams,  Twilight Hours: A Legacy of Verse
Quote: Though my soul may set in darkness, it will rise in perfect light; I have loved the stars too fondly to be fearful of the night.

Author: Bill Watterson
Quote: In my opinion, we don't devote nearly enough scientific research to finding a cure for jerks.

Author: Abraham Lincoln
Quote: I can see how it might be possible for a man to look down upon the earth and be an atheist, but I cannot conceive how a man could look up into the heavens and say there is no God.

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
Quote: For me, it is far better to grasp the Universe as it really is than to persist in delusion, however satisfying and reassuring.

Author: Douglas Adams
Quote: If you try and take a cat apart to see how it works, the first thing you have on your hands is a non-working cat.

Author: Michael Crichton,  State of Fear
Quote: Do you know what we call opinion in the absence of evidence? We call it prejudice.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: Physics is like sex: sure, it may give some practical results, but that's not why we do it.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: Who is more humble? The scientist who looks at the universe with an open mind and accepts whatever the universe has to teach us, or somebody who says everything in this book must be considered the literal truth and never mind the fallibility of all the human beings involved?

Author: Albert Einstein,  The Born-Einstein Letters 1916-55
Quote: God does not play dice with the universe.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: Somewhere, something incredible is waiting to be known.

Author: Ray Bradbury
Quote: We are an impossibility in an impossible universe.

Author: Martin Luther King Jr.
Quote: Science investigates; religion interprets. Science gives man knowledge, which is power; religion gives man wisdom, which is control. Science deals mainly with facts; religion deals mainly with values. The two are not rivals.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: The most incomprehensible thing about the world is that it is at all comprehensible.

Author: R. Buckminster Fuller
Quote: You never change things by fighting the existing reality.To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: Reading, after a certain age, diverts the mind too much from its creative pursuits. Any man who reads too much and uses his own brain too little falls into lazy habits of thinking.

Author: Douglas Adams,  The Salmon of Doubt
Quote: We are stuck with technology when what we really want is just stuff that works.

Author: Abraham Maslow,  Toward a Psychology of Being
Quote: I suppose it is tempting, if the only tool you have is a hammer, to treat everything as if it were a nail.

Author: Galileo Galilei,  Letter to the Grand Duchess Christina
Quote: I do not feel obliged to believe that the same God who has endowed us with sense, reason, and intellect has intended us to forgo their use.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: Student: Dr. Einstein, Aren't these the same questions as last year's [physics] final exam?Dr. Einstein: Yes; But this year the answers are different.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: Wisdom is not a product of schooling but of the lifelong attempt to acquire it.

Author: Stephen Hawking,  A Brief History of Time
Quote: Even if there is only one possible unified theory, it is just a set of rules and equations. What is it that breathes fire into the equations and makes a universe for them to describe? The usual approach of science of constructing a mathematical model cannot answer the questions of why there should be a universe for the model to describe. Why does the universe go to all the bother of existing?

Author: Walt Whitman,  Walt Whitman's Camden Conversations
Quote: I like the scientific spirit—the holding off, the being sure but not too sure, the willingness to surrender ideas when the evidence is against them: this is ultimately fine—it always keeps the way beyond open—always gives life, thought, affection, the whole man, a chance to try over again after a mistake—after a wrong guess.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: Life would be tragic if it weren't funny.

Author: Claude Lévi-Strauss
Quote: The scientist is not a person who gives the right answers, he's one who asks the right questions.

Author: Richard Dawkins
Quote: Science is interesting, and if you don't agree you can fuck off.Note: Dawkins was quoting a former editor of New Scientist Magazine, who is as yet unidentified (possibly Jeremy Webb)

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: If there is any religion that could respond to the needs of modern science, it would be Buddhism.

Author: Isaac Asimov
Quote: Your assumptions are your windows on the world. Scrub them off every once in a while, or the light won't come in.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: We can judge our progress by the courage of our questions and the depth of our answers, our willingness to embrace what is true rather than what feels good.

Author: Thomas Jefferson,  The Statute Of Virginia For Religious Freedom
Quote: Our civil rights have no dependence on our religious opinions any more than our opinions in physics or geometry...

Author: Niels Bohr
Quote: The opposite of a correct statement is a false statement. But the opposite of a profound truth may well be another profound truth.

Author: Terry Pratchett,  Mort
Quote: Scientists have calculated that the chances of something so patently absurd actually existing are millions to one.But magicians have calculated that million-to-one chances crop up nine times out of ten.

Author: Will Durant,  The Story of Philosophy
Quote: Science is organized knowledge. Wisdom is organized life.

Author: George Orwell,  1984
Quote: For, after all, how do we know that two and two make four? Or that the force of gravity works? Or that the past is unchangeable? If both the past and the external world exist only in the mind, and if the mind itself is controllable – what then?

Author: Isaac Newton
Quote: I do not know what I may appear to the world, but to myself I seem to have been only like a boy playing on the sea-shore, and diverting myself in now and then finding a smoother pebble or a prettier shell than ordinary, whilst the great ocean of truth lay all undiscovered before me.

Author: Douglas Adams
Quote: First we thought the PC was a calculator. Then we found out how to turn numbers into letters with ASCII — and we thought it was a typewriter. Then we discovered graphics, and we thought it was a television. With the World Wide Web, we've realized it's a brochure.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: I learned very early the difference between knowing the name of something and knowing something.

Author: Jules Verne,  A Journey to the Center of the Earth
Quote: Science, my lad, is made up of mistakes, but they are mistakes which it is useful to make, because they lead little by little to the truth.

Author: Dan Brown,  Angels & Demons
Quote: Faith is universal. Our specific methods for understanding it are arbitrary. Some of us pray to Jesus, some of us go to Mecca, some of us study subatomic particles. In the end we are all just searching for truth, that which is greater than ourselves.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: One thing I have learned in a long life: that all our science, measured against reality, is primitive and childlike -- and yet it is the most precious thing we have.

Author: John Lubbock,  The Pleasures of Life
Quote: Art is unquestionably one of the purest and highest elements in human happiness. It trains the mind through the eye, and the eye through the mind. As the sun colors flowers, so does art color life.

Author: Dan Barker,  Godless: How an Evangelical Preacher Became One of America's Leading Atheists
Quote: Scientists do not join hands every Sunday and sing "Yes gravity is real! I know gravity is real! I will have faith! I believe in my heart that what goes up, up, up must come down, down, down. Amen!"If they did, we would think they were pretty insecure about the concept.

Author: Philip K. Dick,  Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
Quote: You will be required to do wrong no matter where you go. It is the basic condition of life, to be required to violate your own identity. At some time, every creature which lives must do so. It is the ultimate shadow, the defeat of creation; this is the curse at work, the curse that feeds on all life. Everywhere in the universe.

Author: Nikola Tesla
Quote: The day science begins to study non-physical phenomena, it will make more progress in one decade than in all the previous centuries of its existence.

Author: Clive James
Quote: Common sense and a sense of humor are the same thing, moving at different speeds. A sense of humor is just common sense, dancing.

Author: Antonio Gramsci,  Gramsci's Prison Letters
Quote: I'm a pessimist because of intelligence, but an optimist because of will.

Author: Charles Darwin,  The Descent of Man
Quote: Ignorance more frequently begets confidence than does knowledge: it is those who know little, not those who know much, who so positively assert that this or that problem will never be solved by science.

Author: H.P. Lovecraft
Quote: The most merciful thing in the world, I think, is the inability of the human mind to correlate all its contents... some day the piecing together of dissociated knowledge will open up such terrifying vistas of reality, and of our frightful position therein, that we shall either go mad from the revelation or flee from the light into the peace and safety of a new Dark Age.

Author: Arthur C. Clarke
Quote: How inappropriate to call this planet "Earth,"when it is clearly "Ocean.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: The first principle is that you must not fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool.

Author: Brian Andreas

Author: Carl Sagan,  Cosmos
Quote: We are a way for the cosmos to know itself.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: The more I learn about the universe, the less convinced I am that there's any sort of benevolent force that has anything to do with it, at all.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious. It is the source of all true art and all science. He to whom this emotion is a stranger, who can no longer pause to wonder and stand rapt in awe, is as good as dead: his eyes are closed.

Author: Christopher Hitchens,  God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything
Quote: [E]xceptional claims demand exceptional evidence.

Author: Mark Lawrence,  Prince of Thorns

I looked hot as a chick!

Author: Victor J. Stenger

Author: Carl Sagan

Author: Stephen Hawking

Author: Carl Sagan

Author: Christopher Hitchens,  God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything

We do not rely soley upon science and reason, because these are necessary rather than sufficient factors, but we distrust anything that contradicts science or outrages reason. We may differ on many things, but what we respect is free inquiry, openmindedness, and the pursuit of ideas for their own sake.

Author: Sigmund Freud,  Civilization and Its Discontents

Author: Thomas A. Edison

Author: Bertrand Russell

Author: Stephen Hawking

This leads me to a profound realization that there probably is no heaven and no afterlife either. We have this one life to appreciate the grand design of the universe and for that, I am extremely grateful.

Author: Richard Feynman

Author: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam,  Wings of Fire: An Autobiography

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson

Author: Daniel Kahneman,  Thinking, Fast and Slow

Author: Bill Bryson,  A Short History of Nearly Everything

Author: Carl Sagan,  Contact

Author: Thomas Henry Huxley,  Life and Letters of Thomas Henry Huxley - Volume 1

Author: Richard Feynman,  QED: The Strange Theory of Light and Matter

Author: Santosh Kalwar,  Quote Me Everyday
Quote: Do not become someone else just because you are hurt. Be who you are & smile, it may solve, all problems you have got.

Author: Jane Goodall
Quote: In what terms should we think of these beings, nonhuman yet possessing so very many human-like characteristics? How should we treat them? Surely we should treat them with the same consideration and kindness as we show to other humans; and as we recognize human rights, so too should we recognize the rights of the great apes? Yes.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: We are trying to prove ourselves wrong as quickly as possible, because only in that way can we find progress.

Author: Arthur Schopenhauer,  Parerga and Paralipomena
Quote: Philosophy ... is a science, and as such has no articles of faith; accordingly, in it nothing can be assumed as existing except what is either positively given empirically, or demonstrated through indubitable conclusions.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: There is a fundamental difference between religion, which is based on authority, and science, which is based on observation and reason. Science will win because it works.

Author: Hippocrates
Quote: There are in fact two things, science and opinion; the former begets knowledge, the latter ignorance.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: If you thought that science was certain - well, that is just an error on your part.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: It's a lazy Saturday afternoon, there's a couple lying naked in bed reading Encyclopediea Brittannica to each other, and arguing about whether the Andromeda Galaxy is more 'numinous' than the Ressurection. Do they know how to have a good time, or don't they?

Author: Werner Heisenberg,  Across the Frontiers
Quote: Not only is the Universe stranger than we think, it is stranger than we can think.

Author: John Lubbock,  The Use Of Life
Quote: Rest is not idleness, and to lie sometimes on the grass under trees on a summer's day, listening to the murmur of the water, or watching the clouds float across the sky, is by no means a waste of time.

Author: Madeleine L'Engle,  A Wrinkle in Time: With Related Readings
Quote: A straight line is not the shortest distance between two points.

Author: Rachel Carson,  The Sea Around Us
Quote: It is a curious situation that the sea, from which life first arose should now be threatened by the activities of one form of that life. But the sea, though changed in a sinister way, will continue to exist; the threat is rather to life itself.

Author: John Muir,  My First Summer in the Sierra
Quote: Another glorious Sierra day in which one seems to be dissolved and absorbed and sent pulsing onward we know not where. Life seems neither long nor short, and we take no more heed to save time or make haste than do the trees and stars. This is true freedom, a good practical sort of immortality.

Author: Isaac Newton
Quote: Gravity explains the motions of the planets, but it cannot explain who sets the planets in motion.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: A foolish faith in authority is the worst enemy of truth.

Author: John Muir
Quote: John Muir, Earth — planet, Universe[Muir's home address, as inscribed on the inside front cover of his first field journal]

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: God is an ever receding pocket of scientific ignorance.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: You can know the name of a bird in all the languages of the world, but when you're finished, you'll know absolutely nothing whatever about the bird... So let's look at the bird and see what it's doing -- that's what counts.

Author: Epicurus
Quote: He who is not satisfied with a little, is satisfied with nothing .

Author: Kurt Vonnegut,  The Sirens of Titan
Quote: The bounties of space, of infinite outwardness, were three: empty heroics, low comedy, and pointless death.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: The idea that God is an oversized white male with a flowing beard, who sits in the sky and tallies the fall of every sparrow is ludicrous. But if by 'God,' one means the set of physical laws that govern the universe, then clearly there is such a God. This God is emotionally unsatisfying... it does not make much sense to pray to the law of gravity.

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Varieties of Scientific Experience: A Personal View of the Search for God
Quote: Extinction is the rule. Survival is the exception.

Author: Bill Bryson,  A Short History of Nearly Everything
Quote: In France, a chemist named Pilatre de Rozier tested the flammability of hydrogen by gulping a mouthful and blowing across an open flame, proving at a stroke that hydrogen is indeed explosively combustible and that eyebrows are not necessarily a permanent feature of one's face.

Author: Ben Goldacre,  Bad Science
Quote: You cannot reason people out of a position that they did not reason themselves into.

Author: Adam Smith,  The Wealth of Nations
Quote: Science is the great antidote to the poison of enthusiasm and superstition.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: The human spirit must prevail over technology.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: It is harder to crack prejudice than an atom.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson,  The Sky is Not the Limit: Adventures of an Urban Astrophysicist
Quote: I am convinced that the act of thinking logically cannot possibly be natural to the human mind. If it were, then mathematics would be everybody's easiest course at school and our species would not have taken several millennia to figure out the scientific method.

Author: Augustine of Hippo
Quote: Miracles are not contrary to nature but only contrary to what we know about nature.

Author: Bill Gates
Quote: I agree with people like Richard Dawkins that mankind felt the need for creation myths. Before we really began to understand disease and the weather and things like that, we sought false explanations for them. Now science has filled in some of the realm – not all – that religion used to fill.

Author: Isaac Asimov
Quote: Jokes of the proper kind, properly told, can do more to enlighten questions of politics, philosophy, and literature than any number of dull arguments.

Author: Philip Pullman,  His Dark Materials
Quote: As for what it's against - the story is against those who pervert and misuse religion, or any other kind of doctrine with a holy book and a priesthood and an apparatus of power that wields unchallengeable authority, in order to dominate and suppress human freedoms.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: No amount of experimentation can ever prove me right; a single experiment can prove me wrong.

Author: Steve Martin
Quote: It's so hard to believe in anything anymore. I mean, it's like, religion, you really can't take it seriously, because it seems so mythological, it seems so arbitrary...but, on the other hand, science is just pure empiricism, and by virtue of its method, it excludes metaphysics. I guess I wouldn't believe in anything anymore if it weren't for my lucky astrology mood watch.

Author: Penn Jillette,  God, No!: Signs You May Already Be an Atheist and Other Magical Tales
Quote: If every trace of any single religion were wiped out and nothing were passed on, it would never be created exactly that way again. There might be some other nonsense in its place, but not that exact nonsense. If all of science were wiped out, it would still be true and someone would find a way to figure it all out again.

Author: Christopher Moore
Quote: Science, you don't know, looks like magic.

Author: Richard Dawkins,  The Selfish Gene
Quote: Let us try to teach generosity and altruism, because we are born selfish. Let us understand what our own selfish genes are up to, because we may then at least have the chance to upset their designs, something that no other species has ever aspired to do.

Author: George Carlin,  Brain Droppings
Quote: It turned out I was pretty good in science. But again, because of the small budget, in science class we couldn't afford to do experiments in order to prove theories. We just believed everything. Actually, I think that class was called Religion. Religion class was always an easy class. All you had to do was suspend the logic and reasoning you were being taught in all the other classes.

Author: John Maynard Keynes
Quote: When my information changes, I alter my conclusions. What do you do, sir?

Author: Leo Tolstoy,  War and Peace
Quote: Human science fragments everything in order to understand it, kills everything in order to examine it.

Author: John Burroughs,  Leaf and Tendril
Quote: To find the universal elements enough; to find the air and the water exhilarating; to be refreshed by a morning walk or an evening saunter... to be thrilled by the stars at night; to be elated over a bird's nest or a wildflower in spring — these are some of the rewards of the simple life.

Author: Francis Bacon
Quote: Wonder is the seed of knowledge

Author: Frank Herbert
Quote: A process cannot be understood by stopping it. Understanding must move with the flow of the process, must join it and flow with it.

Author: Bertrand Russell,  What I Believe
Quote: Even if the open windows of science at first make us shiver after the cozy indoor warmth of traditional humanizing myths, in the end the fresh air brings vigor, and the great spaces have a splendor of their own.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: The downside of my celebrity is that I cannot go anywhere in the world without being recognized. It is not enough for me to wear dark sunglasses and a wig. The wheelchair gives me away.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: You see, wire telegraph is a kind of a very, very long cat. You pull his tail in New York and his head is meowing in Los Angeles. Do you understand this? And radio operates exactly the same way: you send signals here, they receive them there. The only difference is that there is no cat.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: Kids are never the problem. They are born scientists. The problem is always the adults. They beat the curiosity out of kids. They outnumber kids. They vote. They wield resources. That's why my public focus is primarily adults.

Author: Patricia Cornwell,  Trace
Quote: rain slowly slides down the glass as if the night is crying.

Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
Quote: Bad times have a scientific value. These are occasions a good learner would not miss.

Author: Bill Gates
Quote: In terms of doing things I take a fairly scientific approach to why things happen and how they happen. I don't know if there's a god or not...

Author: Bertolt Brecht,  Life of Galileo
Quote: The aim of science is not to open the door to infinite wisdom, but to set a limit to infinite error.

Author: Richard Dawkins
Quote: Many of us saw religion as harmless nonsense. Beliefs might lack all supporting evidence but, we thought, if people needed a crutch for consolation, where's the harm? September 11th changed all that.

Author: Cecelia Ahern,  The Gift
Quote: What is it with science these days? Everyone is so quick to believe in it, in all these new scientific discoveries, new pills for this, new pills for that. Get thinner, grow hair, yada, yada, yada, but when it requires a little faith in something you all go crazy.' He shook his head, 'If miracles had chemical equations then everyone would believe.

Author: Edwin Hubble
Quote: Equipped with his five senses, man explores the universe around him and calls the adventure Science.

Author: Michio Kaku,  Hyperspace
Quote: It is often stated that of all the theories proposed in this century, the silliest is quantum theory. In fact, some say that the only thing that quantum theory has going for it is that it is unquestionably correct.

Author: Richard Dawkins,  Unweaving the Rainbow: Science, Delusion and the Appetite for Wonder
Quote: The feeling of awed wonder that science can give us is one of the highest experiences of which the human psyche is capable. It is a deep aesthetic passion to rank with the finest that music and poetry can deliver. It is truly one of the things that make life worth living and it does so, if anything, more effectively if it convinces us that the time we have for living is quite finite.

Author: Karl Popper
Quote: Science may be described as the art of systematic oversimplification.

Author: Frank Zappa
Quote: The essence of Christianity is told us in the Garden of Eden history. The fruit that was forbidden was on the tree of knowledge. The subtext is, 'All the suffering you have is because you wanted to find out what was going on. You could be in the Garden of Eden if you had just kept your fucking mouth shut and hadn't asked any questions.

Author: George Washington
Quote: There is nothing which can better deserve our patronage than the promotion of science and literature. Knowledge is in every country the surest basis of public happiness.

Author: Stephen Hawking,  A Brief History of Time
Quote: If time travel is possible, where are the tourists from the future?

Author: Robert A. Heinlein,  Stranger in a Strange Land
Quote: If you've got the truth you can demonstrate it. Talking doesn't prove it.

Author: Robert M. Pirsig,  Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: An Inquiry Into Values
Quote: For every fact there is an infinity of hypotheses.

Author: Hiromu Arakawa,  Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 2
Quote: Riza: Without his Alchemy he's just...Jean: A little brat who swears a lotMaes: An arrogant pipsqueakRoy: Useless. Just uselessAlphonse: Sorry big brother, I don't know how to add to that...Ed *starts to cry*: YOU'RE ALL PICKING ON ME!!!

Author: Edgar D. Mitchell
Quote: You develop an instant global consciousness, a people orientation, an intense dissatisfaction with the state of the world, and a compulsion to do something about it. From out there on the moon, international politics look so petty. You want to grab a politician by the scruff of the neck and drag him a quarter of a million miles out and say, ‘Look at that, you son of a bitch.

Author: Steven Pinker
Quote: It's natural to think that living things must be the handiwork of a designer. But it was also natural to think that the sun went around the earth. Overcoming naive impressions to figure out how things really work is one of humanity's highest callings.[Can You Believe in God and Evolution? Time Magazine, August 7, 2005]

Author: Bill Watterson
Quote: That's the whole problem with science. You've got a bunch of empiricists trying to describe things of unimaginable wonder.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: A celibate clergy is an especially good idea, because it tends to suppress any hereditary propensity toward fanaticism.

Author: Jules Verne
Quote: Reality provides us with facts so romantic that imagination itself could add nothing to them.

Author: Noam Chomsky
Quote: Science is a bit like the joke about the drunk who is looking under a lamppost for a key that he has lost on the other side of the street, because that's where the light is. It has no other choice.

Author: Michael Crichton,  Jurassic Park
Quote: Discovery is always rape of the natural world. Always.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: We are all star stuff.

Author: Nikola Tesla
Quote: Life is and will ever remain an equation incapable of solution, but it contains certain known factors.

Author: Douglas Adams,  The Restaurant at the End of the Universe
Quote: But what about the End of the Universe? We'll miss the big moment."I've seen it. It's rubbish,"said Zaphod,"nothing but a gnab gib."A what?"Opposite of a big bang. Come on, let's get zappy.

Author: Leonardo da Vinci,  Leonardo's Notebooks
Quote: All sciences are vain and full of errors that are not born of Experience, the mother of all Knowledge.

Author: Julie Kagawa,  The Iron King
Quote: As cities grow and technology takes over the world belief and imagination fade away and so do we.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson,  Death by Black Hole: And Other Cosmic Quandaries
Quote: When scientifically investigating the natural world, the only thing worse than a blind believer is a seeing denier.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: So long as the universe had a beginning, we could suppose it had a creator. But if the universe is really completely self-contained, having no boundary or edge, it would have neither beginning nor end: it would simply be. What place, then, for a creator?

Author: Nikola Tesla,  My Inventions
Quote: Invention is the most important product of man's creative brain. The ultimate purpose is the complete mastery of mind over the material world, the harnessing of human nature to human needs.

Author: Isaac Newton,  The Principia: Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy
Quote: This most beautiful system of the sun, planets and comets, could only proceed from the counsel and dominion of an intelligent and powerful Being.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: For a successful technology, reality must take precedence over public relations, for nature cannot be fooled.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: We are at the very beginning of time for the human race. It is not unreasonable that we grapple with problems. But there are tens of thousands of years in the future. Our responsibility is to do what we can, learn what we can, improve the solutions, and pass them on.

Author: Christopher Hitchens
Quote: We owe a huge debt to Galileo for emancipating us all from the stupid belief in an Earth-centered or man-centered (let alone God-centered) system. He quite literally taught us our place and allowed us to go on to make extraordinary advances in knowledge.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: A society's competitive advantage will come not from how well its schools teach the multiplication and periodic tables, but from how well they stimulate imagination and creativity.

Author: Baruch Spinoza
Quote: I have made a ceaseless effort not to ridicule, not to bewail, not to scorn human actions, but to understand them.

Author: David Hume,  An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding
Quote: In our reasonings concerning matter of fact, there are all imaginable degrees of assurance, from the highest certainty to the lowest species of moral evidence. A wise man, therefore, proportions his belief to the evidence.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: I would teach how science works as much as I would teach what science knows. I would assert (given that essentially, everyone will learn to read) that science literacy is the most important kind of literacy they can take into the 21st century. I would undervalue grades based on knowing things and find ways to reward curiosity. In the end, it's the people who are curious who change the world.

Author: Brian Greene
Quote: Science is the process that takes us from confusion to understanding...

Author: Aleister Crowley,  The Confessions of Aleister Crowley: An Autohagiography
Quote: Science is always discovering odd scraps of magical wisdom and making a tremendous fuss about its cleverness.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson,  Cosmos
Quote: There’s as many atoms in a single molecule of your DNA as there are stars in the typical galaxy. We are, each of us, a little universe.

Author: Bill Gates,  The Road Ahead
Quote: DNA is like a computer program but far, far more advanced than any software ever created.

Author: Christopher Hitchens,  God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything
Quote: God did not create man in his own image. Evidently, it was quite the other way about, which is the painless explanation for the profusion of gods and religions, and the fratricide both between and among faiths, that we see all about us and that has so retarded the development of civilization.

Author: Stephen Jay Gould,  The Flamingo's Smile: Reflections in Natural History
Quote: We have become, by the power of a glorious evolutionary accident called intelligence, the stewards of life's continuity on earth. We did not ask for this role, but we cannot abjure it. We may not be suited to it, but here we are.

Author: Immanuel Kant,  Critique of Practical Reason
Quote: Two things fill the mind with ever new and increasing admiration and awe, the more often and steadily we reflect upon them: the starry heavens above me and the moral law within me. I do not seek or conjecture either of them as if they were veiled obscurities or extravagances beyond the horizon of my vision; I see them before me and connect them immediately with the consciousness of my existence.

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: One of the strongest motives that lead men to art and science is escape from everyday life with its painful crudity and hopeless dreariness, from the fetters of one's own ever-shifting desires. A finely tempered nature longs to escape from the personal life into the world of objective perception and thought.

Author: Ann Druyan
Quote: Interviewer: Didn't Sagan want to believe?Druyan: he didn't want to believe. he wanted to know.

Author: Richard Dawkins
Quote: It has become almost a cliché to remark that nobody boasts of ignorance of literature, but it is socially acceptable to boast ignorance of science and proudly claim incompetence in mathematics.

Author: Socrates
Quote: The greatest blessing granted to mankind come by way of madness, which is a divine gift.

Author: Delos McKown
Quote: The invisible and the non-existent look very much alike.

Author: Robert M. Sapolsky
Quote: I love science, and it pains me to think that so many are terrified of the subject or feel that choosing science means you cannot also choose compassion, or the arts, or be awed by nature. Science is not meant to cure us of mystery, but to reinvent and reinvigorate it.

Author: Anonymous,  Holy Bible: King James Version
Quote: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.

Author: Joss Whedon
Quote: As we all know, blinking lights means science.

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
Quote: The chief deficiency I see in the skeptical movement is its polarization: Us vs. Them — the sense that we have a monopoly on the truth; that those other people who believe in all these stupid doctrines are morons; that if you're sensible, you'll listen to us; and if not, to hell with you. This is nonconstructive. It does not get our message across. It condemns us to permanent minority status.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: I regard the afterlife to be a fairy story for people that are afraid of the dark

Author: Sam Harris,  The End of Faith: Religion, Terror, and the Future of Reason
Quote: Man is manifestly not the measure of all things. This universe is shot through with mystery. The very fact of its being, and of our own, is a mystery absolute, and the only miracle worthy of the name.

Author: Isaac Newton
Quote: What goes up must come down.

Author: Yann Martel,  Life of Pi
Quote: Scientists are a friendly, atheistic, hard-working, beer-drinking lot whose minds are preoccupied with sex, chess and baseball when they are not preoccupied with science.

Author: Carl Sagan,  Contact
Quote: We all have a thirst for wonder. It's a deeply human quality. Science and religion are both bound up with it. What I'm saying is, you don't have to make stories up, you don't have to exaggerate. There's wonder and awe enough in the real world. Nature's a lot better at inventing wonders than we are.

Author: Max Planck,  Scientific Autobiography and Other Papers
Quote: A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing its opponents and making them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die, and a new generation grows up that is familiar with it.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: Science is like sex: sometimes something useful comes out, but that is not the reason we are doing it.

Author: Alan Turing,  Computing machinery and intelligence
Quote: We can only see a short distance ahead, but we can see plenty there that needs to be done.

Author: Wassily Kandinsky,  Concerning the Spiritual in Art
Quote: Colour is a power which directly influences the soul.

Author: Bertrand Russell
Quote: Science is what you know, philosophy is what you don't know

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: We are star stuff harvesting sunlight.

Author: Max Planck,  Where is Science Going?
Quote: Science cannot solve the ultimate mystery of nature. And that is because, in the last analysis, we ourselves are a part of the mystery that we are trying to solve.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Quote: When asked about which scientist he'd like to meet, Neil deGrasse Tyson said, "Isaac Newton. No question about it. The smartest person ever to walk the face of this earth. The man was connected to the universe in spooky ways. He discovered the laws of motion, the laws of gravity, the laws of optics. Then he turned 26.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: Philosophy of science is about as useful to scientists as ornithology is to birds.

Author: Karl Popper
Quote: Whenever a theory appears to you as the only possible one, take this as a sign that you have neither understood the theory nor the problem which it was intended to solve.

Author: Frank Herbert,  Dune
Quote: Highly organized research is guaranteed to produce nothing new.

Author: C.S. Lewis,  Screwtape Letters
Quote: Above all, do not attempt to use science (I mean, the real sciences) as a defence against Christianity. They will positively encourage him to think about realities he can’t touch and see.

Author: Douglas R. Hofstadter,  Metamagical Themas: Questing for the Essence of Mind and Pattern
Quote: It turns out that an eerie type of chaos can lurk just behind a facade of order - and yet, deep inside the chaos lurks an even eerier type of order.

Author: Rick Yancey,  The 5th Wave
Quote: And if humanity is the last war, then I am the battlefield.

Author: Werner Heisenberg
Quote: I remember discussions with Bohr which went through many hours till very late at night and ended almost in despair; and when at the end of the discussion I went alone for a walk in the neighbouring park I repeated to myself again and again the question: Can nature possibly be so absurd as it seemed to us in these atomic experiments?

Author: Hippocrates
Quote: As to diseases, make a habit of two things — to help, or at least, to do no harm.

Author: Michael Crichton
Quote: Everyone has a hidden agenda. Except me!

Author: Sam Harris
Quote: We know enough at this moment to say that the God of Abraham is not only unworthy of the immensity of creation; he is unworthy even of man.

Author: Mary E. Pearson,  The Adoration of Jenna Fox

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
Quote: Avoidable human misery is more often caused not so much by stupidity as by ignorance, particularly our ignorance about ourselves.

Author: Albert Einstein,  On Cosmic Religion and Other Opinions and Aphorisms

Author: Democritus
Quote: Nothing exists except atoms and empty space; everything else is opinion.

Author: Terry Pratchett,  The Color of Magic
Quote: Every intelligent being, whether it breathes or not, coughs nervously at some time in its life.

Author: Thomas Henry Huxley,  Collected Essays Of Thomas Henry Huxley
Quote: The man of science has learned to believe in justification, not by faith, but by verification.

Author: J.B.S. Haldane,  Possible Worlds
Quote: The Universe is not only queerer than we suppose, but queerer than we can suppose.

Author: Ian Stewart,  The Collapse of Chaos: Discovering Simplicity in a Complex World
Quote: If our brains were simple enough for us to understand them, we'd be so simple that we couldn't.

Author: Robert G. Ingersoll,  Thomas Paine From 'The Gods and Other Lectures'

Author: Niels Bohr,  Essays 1932-1957 on Atomic Physics and Human Knowledge

Author: George Head,  A Home Tour Through the Manufacturing Districts of England in the Summer of 1835
Quote: If time be judiciously employed, there is time for everything.

Author: Michael Crichton,  Jurassic Park

Author: Kurt Vonnegut,  The Sirens of Titan
Quote: Mankind flung its advance agents ever outward, ever outward. Eventually it flung them out into space, into the colorless, tasteless, weightless sea of outwardness without end. It flung them like stones.

Quote: Why do humans exist? A major part of the answer: because Pikaia Gracilens survived the Burgess decimation.

Author: Julie Kagawa,  The Iron King

Author: Carl Sagan,  Pale Blue Dot: A Vision of the Human Future in Space

Author: Martin Heidegger
Quote: Thinking only begins at the point where we have come to know that Reason, glorified for centuries, is the most obstinate adversary of thinking.

Author: Bertrand Russell,  A History of Western Philosophy

Author: Albert Einstein
Quote: The significant problems we have cannot be solved at the same level of thinking with which we created them.

Author: Deborah Harkness,  A Discovery of Witches
Quote: The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion that stands at the cradle of true art and true science. Whoever does not know it and can no longer wonder, is as good as dead, and his eyes are dimmed (Albert Einstein)

Author: G.K. Chesterton
Quote: Science must not impose any philosophy, any more than the telephone must tell us what to say.

Author: Timothy Leary,  Chaos & Cyber Culture

Author: Omar Nelson Bradley

Author: Daniel Goleman,  Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More Than IQ
Quote: In a very real sense we have two minds, one that thinks and one that feels

Author: Brandon Sanderson,  The Way of Kings
Quote: Ignorance is hardly unusual, Miss Davar. The longer I live, the more I come to realize that it is the natural state of the human mind. There are many who will strive to defend its sanctity and then expect you to be impressed with their efforts.

Author: Donald Ervin Knuth,  Things a Computer Scientist Rarely Talks About
Quote: Science is what we understand well enough to explain to a computer; art is everything else.

Author: المهدي المنجرة
Quote: لا توجد أي دولة في العالم انطلقت في المجال التكنولوجي دون الاعتماد على اللغة الأم.

Quote: Every great advance in science has issued from a new audacity of imagination.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: There are no forbidden questions in science, no matters too sensitive or delicate to be probed, no sacred truths.

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson,  Death by Black Hole: And Other Cosmic Quandaries

Author: Lloyd Alexander

Author: Graham Parke
Quote: Sadly, my socks are like snowflakes, no two are exactly alike.

Author: Linus Pauling
Quote: I have something that I call my Golden Rule. It goes something like this: 'Do unto others twenty-five percent better than you expect them to do unto you.' … The twenty-five percent is for error.

Author: Robert M. Pirsig,  Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: An Inquiry Into Values
Quote: The real purpose of the scientific method is to make sure nature hasn’t misled you into thinking you know something you actually don’t know.

Author: Theodore Roszak,  Where the Wasteland Ends
Quote: Nature composes some of her loveliest poems for the microscope and the telescope.

Author: Ludwig Wittgenstein

Author: Brandon Sanderson,  Words of Radiance

Author: Paul Farmer
Quote: It is very expensive to give bad medical care to poor people in a rich country.

Author: Carl Sagan,  Cosmos
Quote: If we long for our planet to be important, there is something we can do about it. We make our world significant by the courage of our questions and by the depth of our answers.

Author: Derek Landy,  Death Bringer
Quote: Just because an apple falls one hundred times out of a hundred does not mean it will fall on the hundred and first.

Author: Sam Kean,  The Disappearing Spoon: And Other True Tales of Madness, Love, and the History of the World from the Periodic Table of the Elements
Quote: Never underestimate spite as a motivator for genius.

Author: Rachel Carson
Quote: The more clearly we can focus our attention on the wonders and realities of the universe about us the less taste we shall have for the destruction of our race. Author: Emily Dickinson
Quote: Faith is a fine inventionWhen gentlemen can see,But microscopes are prudentIn an emergency.

Author: Richard Dawkins,  The Selfish Gene

Author: Charles Darwin,  The Origin of Species
Quote: One general law, leading to the advancement of all organic beings, namely, multiply, vary, let the strongest live and the weakest die.

Author: Nicholas Sparks,  The Notebook
Quote: Science only goes so far, then comes God.- Noah Calhoun-

Author: Michael Faraday
Quote: Nothing is too wonderful to be true if it be consistent with the laws of nature.

Author: Arne Tiselius
Quote: We live in a world where unfortunately the distinction between true and false appears to become increasingly blurred by manipulation of facts, by exploitation of uncritical minds, and by the pollution of the language.

Author: Larry Niven
Quote: Mother Nature doesn't care if you're having fun.

Author: Arthur C. Clarke
Quote: When a distinguished but elderly scientist states that something is possible, he is almost certainly right. When he states that something is impossible, he is very probably wrong.

Author: Santiago Ramón y Cajal,  Advice for a Young Investigator
Quote: Any man could, if he were so inclined, be the sculptor of his own brain.

Author: Isaac Asimov,  The Roving Mind
Quote: I believe in evidence. I believe in observation, measurement, and reasoning, confirmed by independent observers. I'll believe anything, no matter how wild and ridiculous, if there is evidence for it. The wilder and more ridiculous something is, however, the firmer and more solid the evidence will have to be.

Author: Margaret Atwood,  Oryx and Crake
Quote: We understand more than we know.

Author: Richard Dawkins
Quote: Science replaces private prejudice with public, verifiable evidence.

Author: Richard Dawkins,  A Devil's Chaplain: Reflections on Hope, Lies, Science, and Love
Quote: Even those who do not, or cannot, avail themselves of a scientific education, choose to benefit from the technology that is made possible by the scientific education of others.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: Science is based on experiment, on a willingness to challenge old dogma, on an openness to see the universe as it really is. Accordingly, science sometimes requires courage - at the very least the courage to question the conventional wisdom.

Author: Anne McCaffrey,  Acorna: The Unicorn Girl
Quote: A real scientist solves problems, not wails that they are unsolvable.

Author: François Rabelais,  Pantagruel
Quote: Science without conscience is the soul's perdition.

Author: Bertrand Russell,  The Impact of Science on Society

Author: Thomas Henry Huxley,  Life and Letters of Thomas Henry Huxley - Volume 1
Quote: I am too much of a skeptic to deny the possibility of anything.

Author: Aldo Leopold,  Round River: From the Journals of Aldo Leopold
Quote: We shall never achieve harmony with the land, anymore than we shall achieve absolute justice or liberty for people. In these higher aspirations the important thing is not to achieve but to strive.

Author: J.B.S. Haldane
Quote: The four stages of acceptance:1. This is worthless nonsense.2. This is an interesting, but perverse, point of view.3. This is true, but quite unimportant.4. I always said so."(Review of The Truth About Death, in: Journal of Genetics 1963, Vol. 58, p.464)

Quote: For someone who'e smarter than a supercomputer, sometimes you're a real idiot.

Author: Thomas Paine,  The Age of Reason

Author: Humphry Davy
Quote: Nothing is so dangerous to the progress of the human mind than to assume that our views of science are ultimate, that there are no mysteries in nature, that our triumphs are complete and that there are no new worlds to conquer.

Author: Stephen Hawking

Author: Galileo Galilei,  Frammenti e lettere
Quote: My dear Kepler, what would you say of the learned here, who, replete with the pertinacity of the asp, have steadfastly refused to cast a glance through the telescope? What shall we make of this? Shall we laugh, or shall we cry?

Author: Max Planck,  Where is Science Going?
Quote: It is not the possession of truth, but the success which attends the seeking after it, that enriches the seeker and brings happiness to him.

Author: Arthur Conan Doyle,  The Hound of the Baskervilles
Quote: It is not my intention to be fulsome, but I confess that I covet your skull.

Author: Lawrence M. Krauss,  A Universe from Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing
Quote: If we wish to draw philosophical conclusions about our own existence, our significance, and the significance of the universe itself, our conclusions should be based on empirical knowledge. A truly open mind means forcing our imaginations to conform to the evidence of reality, and not vice versa, whether or not we like the implications.

Author: Jostein Gaarder,  Sophie's World
Quote: And although I have seen nothing but black crows in my life, it doesn't mean that there's no such thing as a white crow. Both for a philosopher and for a scientist it can be important not to reject the possibility of finding a white crow. You might almost say that hunting for 'the white crow' is science's principal task.

Author: Albert Pike
Quote: We must pass through the darkness, to reach the light.

Author: Paul Erdős
Quote: [When asked why are numbers beautiful?]It’s like asking why is Ludwig van Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony beautiful. If you don't see why, someone can't tell you. I know numbers are beautiful. If they aren't beautiful, nothing is.

Author: Rachel Carson
Quote: The question is whether any civilization can wage relentless war on life without destroying itself, and without losing the right to be called civilized.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: We can't help it. Life looks for life.

Author: George Gordon Byron
Quote: The bright sun was extinguish'd, and the starsDid wander darkling in the eternal space.

Author: Tim Minchin
Quote: Science adjusts its views based on what's observedFaith is the denial of observation so that belief can be preserved.

Author: Michael Shermer
Quote: There are many sources of spirituality; religion may be the most common, but it is by no means the only. Anything that generates a sense of awe may be a source of spirituality. Science does this in spades.

Author: Daniel C. Dennett,  Sweet Dreams: Philosophical Obstacles to a Science of Consciousness
Quote: Not a single one of the cells that compose you knows who you are, or cares.

Author: Criss Jami,  Killosophy
Quote: It's much easier on the emotions when one sees life as an experiment rather than a struggle for popularity.

Author: Robert K. Merton,  Social Theory and Social Structure
Quote: Most institutions demand unqualified faith; but the institution of science makes skepticism a virtue.

Author: Albert Einstein,  Autobiographical Notes
Quote: Something deeply hidden had to be behind things.

Author: Santosh Kalwar
Quote: My dream, is to dream, a dream.

Author: Luther Burbank
Quote: Flowers always make people better, happier, and more helpful; they are sunshine, food and medicine to the mind.

Author: Ann Druyan
Quote: And what greater might do we possess as human beings than our capacity to question and to learn?

Author: Albert Hofmann
Quote: It's very, very dangerous to lose contact with living nature.

Author: Leonard Susskind,  The Black Hole War: My Battle with Stephen Hawking to Make the World Safe for Quantum Mechanics
Quote: There is a philosophy that says that if something is unobservable -- unobservable in principle -- it is not part of science. If there is no way to falsify or confirm a hypothesis, it belongs to the realm of metaphysical speculation, together with astrology and spiritualism. By that standard, most of the universe has no scientific reality -- it's just a figment of our imaginations.

Author: K.J. Parker
Quote: The easiest way to do anything is properly.

Author: Chris Hedges,  American Fascists: The Christian Right and the War on America
Quote: The split in America, rather than simply economic, is between those who embrace reason, who function in the real world of cause and effect, and those who, numbed by isolation and despair, now seek meaning in a mythical world of intuition, a world that is no longer reality-based, a world of magic.

Author: Erwin Schrödinger
Quote: Consciousness cannot be accounted for in physical terms. For consciousness is absolutely fundamental. It cannot be accounted for in terms of anything else.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: The way to find out about our place in the universe is by examining the universe and by examining ourselves - without preconceptions, with as unbiased a mind as we can muster.

Author: Siddhartha Mukherjee,  The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer
Quote: History repeats, but science reverberates.

Author: Karl Pilkington,  The Ricky Gervais Show - First, Second and Third Seasons
Quote: They keep saying that sea levels are rising an' all this. It's nowt to do with the icebergs melting, it's because there's too many fish in it. Get rid of some of the fish and the water will drop. Simple. Basic science.

Author: Michael Specter
Quote: People wrap themselves in their beliefs. And they do it in such a way that you can't set them free. Not even the truth will set them free.

Author: Jules Verne,  Journey to the Center of the Earth
Quote: Science, my boy, is made up of mistakes, but they are mistakes which it is useful to make, because they lead little by little to the truth.

Author: Michael Crichton,  Prey
Quote: They didn't understand what they were doing.I'm afraid that will be on the tombstone of the human race.

Author: Michael Crichton,  Next
Quote: Science is as corruptible a human activity as any other.

Author: Evelyn Fox Keller,  Reflections on Gender and Science
Quote: To know the history of science is to recognize the mortality of any claim to universal truth.

Author: Amit Ray,  Om Chanting & Meditation
Quote: Om (AUM) the Divine song is at the same time Symmetry, Supersymmetry, broken Symmetry, and the unbroken Symmetry of Nature.

Author: Charles Darwin,  The Origin of Species
Quote: Nothing is easier than to admit in words the truth of the universal struggle for life, or more difficult--at least I have found it so--than constantly to bear this conclusion in mind.

Author: Bertrand Russell
Quote: It is not what the man of science believes that distinguishes him, but how and why he believes it. His beliefs are tentative, not dogmatic; they are based on evidence, not on authority or intuition.

Author: Niels Bohr
Quote: Stop telling God what to do with his dice.

Author: Carl Sagan
Quote: [When a religious couple wrote to Sagan about fulfilled prophecies, he wrote back in May 1996:]If ‘fulfilled prophecy’ is your criterion, why do you not believe in materialistic science, which has an unparalleled record of fulfilled prophecy? Consider, for example, eclipses.

Author: Erwin Schrödinger,  What Is Life? with Mind and Matter and Autobiographical Sketches
Quote: The scientist only imposes two things, namely truth and sincerity, imposes them upon himself and upon other scientists.

Author: Dan Brown,  Angels & Demons
Quote: Science tells me God must exist.My mind tells me I'll never understand God.My heart tells me I'm not meant to. [Vittoria Vetra]

Author: Dorothy L. Sayers,  Gaudy Night
Quote: The only ethical principle which has made science possible is that the truth shall be told all the time. If we do not penalize false statements made in error, we open up the way for false statements by intention. And a false statement of fact, made deliberately, is the most serious crime a scientist can commit.

Author: Stanisław Lem,  Solaris
Quote: We don't want to conquer the cosmos, we simply want to extend the boundaries of Earth to the frontiers of the cosmos.

Author: Kim Stanley Robinson,  Blue Mars
Quote: Economics was like psychology, a pseudoscience trying to hide that fact with intense theoretical hyperelaboration. And gross domestic product was one of those unfortunate measurement concepts, like inches or the British thermal unit, that ought to have been retired long before.

Author: Edward O. Wilson
Quote: One planet, one experiment.

Author: David Brin,  Brightness Reef
Quote: Creative people see Prometheus in a mirror, never Pandora.

Author: Charles Darwin,  Notebooks
Quote: We can allow satellites, planets, suns, universe, nay whole systems of universe, to be governed by laws, but the smallest insect, we wish to be created at once by special act.

Author: Alexander Pope
Quote: Nature and Nature's laws lay hid in night:God said, Let Newton be! and all was light.

Author: Will Durant
Quote: Civilization exists by geological consent, subject to change without notice.

Author: Bill Bryson,  A Short History of Nearly Everything
Quote: Energy is liberated matter, matter is energy waiting to happen.

Author: Steven Weinberg
Quote: The effort to understand the universe is one of the very few things that lifts human life a little above the level of farce, and gives it some of the grace of tragedy.

Author: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin
Quote: The most telling and profound way of describing the evolution of the universe would undoubtedly be to trace the evolution of love.

Author: Robert M. Pirsig,  Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: An Inquiry Into Values
Quote: We have artists with no scientific knowledge and scientists with noartistic knowledge and both with no spiritual sense of gravity at all,and the result is not just bad, it is ghastly.

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
Quote: But I try not to think with my gut. If I'm serious about understanding the world, thinking with anything besides my brain, as tempting as that might be, is likely to get me into trouble.

Author: Rachel Carson
Quote: The winds, the sea, and the moving tides are what they are. If there is wonder and beauty and majesty in them, science will discover these qualities... If there is poetry in my book about the sea, it is not because I deliberately put it there, but because no one could write truthfully about the sea and leave out the poetry.

Author: René Descartes
Quote: But in my opinion, all things in nature occur mathematically.

Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
Quote: Men love to wonder, and that is the seed of science.

Author: Mary Roach,  Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers

Author: Carl Sagan,  Cosmos

Author: Barack Obama,  The Audacity of Hope: Thoughts on Reclaiming the American Dream
Quote: A nation that can't control its energy sources can't control its future.

Author: Richard Feynman

Author: Richard Dawkins,  The God Delusion

Author: Adam Savage
Quote: When in doubt, C-4.

Author: William James,  The Will to Believe and Other Essays in Popular Philosophy

Author: Eoin Colfer,  The Time Paradox

Author: Enrico Bombieri

Author: Robert Jordan,  The Great Hunt

Author: Henry David Thoreau

Author: H.L. Mencken

Author: Robert H. Goddard

Author: Ben Goldacre,  Bad Science

Author: Philip Pullman,  The Golden Compass

Author: Douglas Adams,  The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
Quote: What does it matter? Science has achieved some wonderful things, of course, but I'd far rather be happy than right any day.

Author: Carl Sagan,  Cosmos
Quote: When we look up at night and view the stars, everything we see is shinning because of distant nuclear fusion.

Author: Robert G. Ingersoll,  Humboldt From 'The Gods and Other Lectures'

Author: Claudius Galenus

Author: Aldo Leopold

Author: J. Robert Oppenheimer

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark

Author: Daniel M. Greenberger

Author: Mary Shelley

Author: Carl Sagan,  Contact

Author: Thomas Aquinas

Author: Tim O'Brien,  Tomcat In Love

Author: Albert Szent-Györgyi
Quote: Discovery consists of looking at the same thing as everyone else and thinking something different.

Author: Karl Marx,  Capital, Vol 1: A Critical Analysis of Capitalist Production
Quote: There is no royal road to science, and only those who do not dread the fatiguing climb of its steep paths have a chance of gaining its luminous summits.

Author: Michael J. Behe,  Darwin's Black Box: The Biochemical Challenge to Evolution

Author: Werner Heisenberg,  Physics and Philosophy: The Revolution in Modern Science

Author: Antoine Lavoisier,  Traité élémentaire de chimie

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: Science is what we have learned about how to keep from fooling ourselves.

Author: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin,  The Phenomenon of Man

Author: Stephen Jay Gould

We may yearn for a ‘higher answer’– but none exists

Author: Dorothy L. Sayers,  The Letters of Dorothy L. Sayers. Vol. 1, 1899-1936: The Making of a Detective Novelist

Author: Rachel Carson

Author: Santosh Kalwar

Author: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk
Quote: Science is the most reliable guide in life.

Author: Michael Crichton,  Jurassic Park
Quote: Nobody is driven by abstractions like 'seeking truth.

Author: Carl Sagan,  The Varieties of Scientific Experience: A Personal View of the Search for God

Author: Jules Verne,  A Journey to the Center of the Earth

Author: Will Durant
